name: Steak Tartare
description: A classic French bistro dish of finely chopped raw beef, seasoned and served with a raw egg yolk and various accompaniments.
ingredients: 10 oz high-quality beef tenderloin or sirloin, very finely chopped
2 tbsp finely minced red onion or shallot
A few dashes of hot sauce (optional)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
Toasted baguette slices or crackers, for serving
instructions: Ensure your beef is of the highest quality and as fresh as possible. Use a sharp knife to finely chop the beef, avoiding a food processor which can make it mushy.

In a medium bowl, combine the chopped beef, capers, cornichons, red onion, Dijon mustard, parsley, olive oil, Worcestershire sauce, and hot sauce. Gently mix with a fork until just combined. Do not overmix.
Season the mixture generously with salt and black pepper.
Divide the mixture into two equal portions. Using a ring mold or your hands, form each portion into a patty on a serving plate.
Create a small indentation in the center of each patty and carefully place a raw egg yolk in it.
Serve immediately with toasted baguette slices and any extra condiments on the side.

name: Ratatouille
description: A rustic and flavorful vegetable stew from Provence, featuring a medley of summer vegetables simmered in a rich tomato sauce.
ingredients: 2 bell peppers (one red, one yellow), diced
1 (28 oz) can whole peeled tomatoes, crushed
1 tbsp fresh herbs (thyme, oregano, basil), chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
instructions: Heat olive oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add the eggplant, zucchini, and bell peppers. Sauté for 5-7 minutes until they begin to soften. Remove the vegetables and set them aside.
Add the chopped onion to the pot and cook until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes. Stir in the minced garlic and cook for 1 minute more until fragrant.
Add the crushed tomatoes, vegetable broth, and fresh herbs to the pot. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a simmer.

Return the sautéed vegetables to the pot. Stir to combine, reduce heat to low, cover, and let it simmer for at least 30 minutes, or up to an hour, to allow the flavors to meld. The vegetables should be very tender.
Serve hot as a main course with crusty bread or as a side dish to roasted meats.

name: French Onion Soup
description: A classic, savory soup made with a rich beef broth and caramelized onions, topped with a large crouton and a generous layer of melted Gruyère cheese.
ingredients: 1/4 cup dry sherry or dry white wine (optional)
Salt and black pepper to taste
instructions: In a large pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter and olive oil over medium-low heat. Add the sliced onions and a pinch of salt. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 45-60 minutes until the onions are deeply caramelized and a rich brown color.
Sprinkle the sugar over the onions and stir for 2 minutes. Pour in the sherry or wine to deglaze the pan, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom. Cook until the liquid has evaporated.
Add the beef broth and bring the soup to a simmer. Season with salt and pepper, then reduce heat to low and let it simmer for 20-30 minutes.
Preheat your oven's broiler. Ladle the soup into oven-safe bowls. Place a slice of baguette on top of each bowl and sprinkle generously with shredded Gruyère.
Place the bowls on a baking sheet and broil for 2-3 minutes, or until the cheese is melted, golden, and bubbly. Serve immediately, being careful as the bowls will be very hot.

name: Boeuf Bourguignon
description: A hearty French beef stew braised in red wine, along with pearl onions, mushrooms, and carrots. A true classic of French cuisine.
ingredients: 3 lbs beef chuck, cut into 1.5-inch cubes
4 oz thick-cut bacon or pancetta, diced
1 (750 ml) bottle dry red wine (like Burgundy or Pinot Noir)
instructions: Pat the beef cubes dry and season with salt and pepper. In a large Dutch oven or oven-safe pot, heat 1 tbsp olive oil over medium-high heat. Brown the beef in batches and set aside.
Add the diced bacon to the pot and cook until crispy. Remove the bacon with a slotted spoon and set aside. Pour off all but 2 tbsp of the bacon fat.
Add the chopped onion and sliced carrots to the pot and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the minced garlic and cook for 1 minute more.

Stir in the tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes. Pour in the red wine, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom. Return the beef and bacon to the pot along with the beef broth, bay leaf, and thyme sprigs. Bring to a simmer.
Cover the pot and transfer it to an oven preheated to 325°F (160°C). Braise for 2-2.5 hours, or until the beef is very tender.
In a separate skillet, sauté the pearl onions and mushrooms in a little oil until golden. Add them to the stew for the last 30 minutes of cooking.
Remove the bay leaf and thyme stems before serving. Serve the stew hot over mashed potatoes or with a side of crusty bread.
